greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle P, read by rows, that satisfies [P^7](n,k) = P(n+1,k+1) for n>=k>=0, also [P^(7*m)](n,k) = [P^m](n+1,k+1) for all m, where [P^m](n,k) denotes the element at row n, column k, of the matrix power m of P, with P(0,k)=1 and P(k,k)=1 for all k>=0.
comment: Also P(n,k) = partitions of (7^n - 7^(n-k)) into powers of 7 <= 7^(n-k).
formula: Let q=7; the g.f. of column k of P^m (ignoring leading zeros) equals: 1 + Sum_{n>=1} (m*q^k)^n/n! * Product_{j=0..n-1} L(q^j*x) where L(x) satisfies: x/(1-x) = Sum_{n>=1} Product_{j=0..n-1} L(q^j*x)/(j+1) and L(x) equals the g.f. of column 0 of the matrix log of P (A111834).
example: Let q=7; the g.f. of column k of matrix power P^m is:
Thus the g.f. of column 0 of matrix power P^m is:
where P^7 shifts columns left and up one place:
program: (PARI) P(n,k,q=7)=local(A=Mat(1),B);if(n<k || k<0,0, for(m=1,n+1,B=matrix(m,m);for(i=1,m, for(j=1,i, if(j==i || j==1,B[i,j]=1,B[i,j]=(A^q)[i-1,j-1]);));A=B); return(A[n+1,k+1]))
results.author: _Gottfried Helms_ and _Paul D. Hanna_, Aug 22 2005
